dt: {bc}to enhance the appearance of especially with beautiful objects
{bc}to enliven or decorate as if with ornaments

dt.t: people of fashion who {wi}adorned{/wi} the Court

pt: {sc}adorn{/sc} {sc}decorate{/sc} {sc}ornament{/sc} {sc}embellish{/sc} {sc}beautify{/sc} {sc}deck{/sc} {sc}garnish{/sc} mean to enhance the appearance of something by adding something unessential. {sc}adorn{/sc} implies an enhancing by something beautiful in itself.
{sc}decorate{/sc} suggests relieving plainness or monotony by adding beauty of color or design.
{sc}ornament{/sc} and {sc}embellish{/sc} imply the adding of something extraneous, {sc}ornament{/sc} stressing the heightening or setting off of the original

pt.t: a white house {it}ornamented{/it} with green shutters

pt: , {sc}embellish{/sc} often stressing the adding of superfluous or adventitious ornament.
{sc}beautify{/sc} adds to {sc}embellish{/sc} a suggestion of counterbalancing plainness or ugliness.

pt.t: will {it}beautify{/it} the grounds with flower beds

pt: {sc}deck{/sc} implies the addition of something that contributes to gaiety, splendor, or showiness.

pt.t: a house all {it}decked{/it} out for Christmas

pt: {sc}garnish{/sc} suggests decorating with a small final touch and is used especially in referring to the serving of food.

et: Middle English {it}aournen, adournen,{/it} borrowed from Anglo-French {it}aurner, adourner{/it} (with {it}d{/it} restored from Latin), going back to Latin {it}adōrnāre{/it} "to get ready, prepare, decorate, embellish," from {it}ad-{/it} {et_link|ad-|ad-} + {it}ōrnāre{/it} "to prepare, equip, embellish" {ma}{mat|ornate|}{/ma}
shortdef: to enhance the appearance of especially with beautiful objects
to enliven or decorate as if with ornaments
